bibl.title: Chin Hing v. United States of America. Bail Bond
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the United States District Court, In and For the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Chin Hing, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus. } No. 2857 Bail Bond

Whereas, Chin Hing, by and through his Attorney, John J. Sullivan, filed an application in the above entitled Court for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, which said Writ was after hearing discharged by the Honorable Heremiah Neterer, Judge in and for theWestern District of Washington, Northern Divison, and said petitioner remanded to the custody of the United States Commissioner of Immigration; and

Whereas, the said petitioner, Chin Hing, by and through his Attorney, John J. Sullivan, has appealed from said Order and Judgment entered on the 29th day of May, 1915, to the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit; and

Whereas, pending said appeal the above entitled Court has required the said petitioner, Chin Hing to be enlarged upon furnishing a Bail Bond in the sum of ONe Thousand Five Hundred ($1500.00) Dollars, with sufficient sureties for the appearance of said Chin Hing in the above entitled court, in case said Decree and Order and Judgment be affirmed.

Now, therefore, know all men by these presents: that we, Chin Hing, as principal, by and through his Attorney, John J. Sullivan, and National Surety Company, a corportation, as sureties, are held and firmly bound unto the United States in the penal sum of One Thousand Five Hundred ($1500.00) Dollars, for the payment of which well and truly to be made they bind 1.
themselves, their heirs executors, administrators and assigns, jointly and serverally, by these presents,
Sealed with their seals and dated this 1 day of June, 1915.

The condition of the above obligation is such that if the above mentioned Chin Hing shall at all times render himself amenable to the orders and processes of the above entitled court, in case said Decree of the above entitled court be affirmed by the Circuit Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit, and will appear for judgment in case it be ultimately determined that the said petitioner is not entitled to a Writ of Habeas Corpus, and is remanded to the custody of the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, then this obligation to be void; otherwise to remain in full force and effect.
div1.ab: By John J Sullivan Attorney for Petitioner Chin Hing
div1.p: National Surety Company By J Sullivan Attorney-in-fact
C.K.Allen US Atty
State of Washington County of King } ss
Appointed Jeremiah Neterer Judge

being first duly sworn, each for himself deposes and says:That he is one of the parties who executed the foregoing bail bond as surety; that he is worth the sum of Three Thousant ($3,000.00) Dollars over and above all his just debts and liabilities in statutory, separate property siutated in King County, State of Washington, not by law exempt from sale on execution; that he is not an attorney or counselor at law, Clerk of the Superior Court, County Clerk, or other City, County or State official.
No. 2875 Original
In the U.S. SuperiorDistrict Court
In and For the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Chin Hing, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Bail Bond
Filed in the U.S. District Court Western Dist of Washington Northern Division JUN % 1915 Frank L. Crosby By EML Deputy 2x
Beeler & Sullivan Lawyers 510-11 White Building Seattle, Wash.
